The challenges they have range from trying to counteract AIDS and other health problems to the most basic things like providing fresh running water for villages. As the leading nation in the South Pacific, there is a double responsibility on us to do something about the nations in our region. Going back to that $180 billion, in any normal year we allocate just over one per cent of federal expenditure to foreign aid, compared with the 44 per cent-a figure I heard in the parliament only this week-that is spent on social security and welfare. In 2004-05 Australia will provide $2.133 billion worth of official development assistance, an increase of $239 million on the amount given in 2003-04. As I said before, quite apart from the aspect of common humanity, at a more practical level Australia’s national interest is served by stability in our region. Of that $2.1 billion I talked about, $805 million goes principally to Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. We know the challenges that are being experienced there. In the case of Papua New Guinea, being the last colonial power to rule New Guinea we are obliged by international protocol to make an ‘over and above’ effort. In the poorer parts of Asia we give just under $500 million-surely no-one would begrudge that-and for other parts of Asia, Africa and the Middle East, $206 million. When you break it up like that it is not a lot of money. The other thing we and the critics should remember is that a lot of that aid comes back to Australia in purchases. It is not just money going offshore. Australian companies and professional bodies that provide services to those countries enjoy some of the benefit of that. Of course we do not do that with that in mind, but in net terms it is not a lot of money going out of Australia. I hope that this tsunami will serve to make us a much more sensitive nation to these disasters. The previous speaker, the member for Hindmarsh, spoke of the devastation on the Eyre Peninsula of South Australia from the recent bushfires. There should be spontaneity in this country; we should not be so inwardly focused at a time when the country is enjoying a relatively high standard of living and prosperity. I ask in my closing remarks that the government and Australia’s scientific agencies do everything they can to play a part in tsunami warning systems. The tsunami earthquake would not need to have occurred many more miles to the west for it to also have affected the north-west coast of Australia. We also have a lot of coastal communities-more of them than we sometimes realise. In fact, most of the nation is built around the eastern and southern seaboards. We should remember that our own vulnerability could be an issue. There are stories in North Queensland of a tsunami back in the 19th century that hit an isolated part of North Queensland. SoI call on those scientific agencies to be very focused and very generous as we develop a tsunami warning system for the Pacific and Indian oceans. Let us hope this dreadful circumstance never occurs again. Debate (on motion by Mr Baldwin) adjourned. MAIN COMMITTEE That the Main Committee do now adjourn. Papua New Guinea Papua New Guinea, it is surprising how little coverage and attention events in Papua New Guinea receive in the Australian media. One honourable exception is the Melbourne Age correspondent Mark Forbes, who from time to time puts together particularly interesting stories in relation to Papua New Guinea. I draw the chamber’s attention to an article that appeared in the Melbourne Age on 4 December entitled ‘Policing a country in crisis’. This article arises from the deployment in support of Papua New Guinea of a vanguard of the Australian Federal Police accompanied by a number of civil servants, which was called the Enhanced Cooperation Program. What struck me in this article was a quote from the Papua New Guinea Police Minister, Bire Kimisopa. He said the Papua New Guinea police force ‘is no longer functioning’. Those are the words of the Papua New Guinea Police Minister. He talks about the police force as a ‘cul-de-sac of corruption’. I know Bire Kimisopa quite well. He strikes me as a man of undoubted integrity and capacity. When he is quoted as having made those sorts of observations, we need to take them very seriously indeed and support him in the courageous role he plays. Mark Forbes followed this up with another story in the Age on 19 February entitled ‘Mafia, corrupt police cripple PNG bid for law and order’. Bire Kimisopa, talking about the influence of organised crime in Papua New Guinea, says ‘it goes right to the top’. The article talks about an investigation by the Age uncovering links between 16 of PNG’s most senior police and Asian criminals implicated in people-smuggling, money laundering, prostitution, illegal gambling, fraud and theft. I simply want to alert the House to the difficulties that Papua New Guinea faces and the importance of Australia’s support. When the Enhanced Cooperation Program was announced by the government, it attracted opposition support. I, as the relevant shadow minister, and the then leader, Mark Latham, put out a media statement endorsing the program and giving our best wishes to the Australian police who commenced the deployment in quite dangerous circumstances. The evidence of problems, though, continues with a report to the PNG government, produced last year by an inquiry into the Papua New Guinea police force. The report made comments such as ‘The Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary has lost its integrity’. It talks about the lawless behaviour of some police having destroyed community confidence and trust. It simply illustrates the difficulty of the environment and the importance of the role the Australian police will be undertaking. Whilst Labor have supported the government’s approach on this, there are a number of matters at present that we think need considerable attention. The revelations, particularly by Mark Forbes, of somewhat more sophisticated, typically Asian based criminals infiltrating Papua New Guinea lend importance to the need not only for policemen on the beat but also for a more sophisticated approach to developing the critical infrastructure that Papua New Guinea needs for effective law enforcement. This will include adding significantly to the PNG capacity in communications and their capacity in relation to forensics, and it is particularly MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Indian Ocean Tsunami

speaker: Mr Baldwin (Paterson) (11.40 A.m.)
theText: I move:
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Sercombe (Maribyrnong) (11.41 A.m.)
theText: For a country as important to Australia asimportant in the light of the sorts of comments that I have alluded to that we strengthen the police internal affairs function. It is also very important indeed, in my view, that this government engages in dialogue with the Papua New Guinean government to look at expanding the enhanced cooperation package beyond its present bilateral basis to a basis where other Pacific nations can have the opportunity to support Australia in its role in Papua New Guinea in the sort of way that Pacific nations are working with Australia in the RAMSI exercise in the Solomon Islands. Papua New Guinea has been a very strong advocate indeed of Pacific regionalism and I believe the current law and order difficulties that are reaching crisis proportions in this country really do require a regional approach, not just a bilateral approach, involving Australia. Cockatoo Fire Brigade bert and Captain Stephen Cameron from the Cockatoo Fire Brigade. They were greatly concerned about a replacement tanker for their local area. I recall the Ash Wednesday bushfires, which affected La Trobe, of 16 February 1983. These fires left a dramatic debt, calculated in today’s terms at roughly $1 billion, not to mention the tragic loss of lives, many of whom were local CFA officers. Following these fires, the Cockatoo Fire Brigade took it upon themselves to sew the initiative to develop and build a tanker capable of carrying 10,000 litres of water, which is four times the amount which a standard fire tanker can hold. This extra water capacity has proven to be extremely successful as it enables a tanker and its crew to remain at a fire scene rather than go back three or four times to refill. It is because of this unique advantage that the Cockatoo brigade will often receive calls from other fire brigades seeking assistance throughout the state. The Cockatoo tanker has played a major role in firefighting throughout the electorate of La Trobe. The region itself, with the lack of reticulated water supplies and the fire sensitive vegetation, gives much justification for a tanker with a much larger water capacity than normal. A suitable replacement is in the best interests of the community. Unfortunately, the brigade owned tanker is fast coming to the end of its 25-year life span. The Cockatoo brigade have been informed that they will be required to remove their current tanker from the roads within the next year or so as it is around 20 years old and will no longer be roadworthy. Whilst the Cockatoo brigade have raised more than $80,000 thus far, further funding of approximately $200,000 is still required to build a replacement tanker by 2007. Through my office I contacted the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment and spoke to Gary Morgan, who is in charge of the state government’s emergency services. I was informed that it was an internal issue for the Country Fire Authority to resolve. The state provides between 20 and 25 per cent of the annual budget, with insurance companies contributing the majority of funding, at close to 70 per cent, mainly through fire service levies. It is up to the Country Fire Authority to allocate funds to the relevant branches as they see fit. This tanker has provided an essential service in defending the community against fires throughout the region. It is especially useful in La Trobe as this region lacks sufficient reticulated water supplies and is prone to bushfires. Letters of support and recognition from surrounding brigades have included Emerald, the Pakenham group, Macclesfield, Lang Lang and the Dandenong Ranges group, all of whom thank the Cockatoo brigade for their assisMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Wood (La Trobe) (11.46 A.m.)
theText: On 31 January 2005, I had a meeting with Stan Hibtance in the past and express their concern that the tanker will be removed from the region without an adequate replacement. I am vitally concerned that if we lose this tanker and it is not replaced we may have a devastating bushfire in the future without the area being properly resourced. I had first-hand experience of the destructive force of the Ash Wednesday bushfires. At the time. I was 16 years of age and I can recall the fires starting in the Dandenong Ranges. I have written to the Victorian Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Tim Holding, urging him to intervene and replace the Cockatoo tanker. We need to ensure that we provide the best support and training to our CFA volunteers, who have been doing a fantastic job, and that they have the best equipment to prevent another Ash Wednesday bushfire. Defence: Equipment liament’s Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I have spoken out in relation to my concerns about the need for Australia to maintain air superiority in our region and about this government’s improper management of our air assets-in particular, their decision to bring forward by 10 years the date of retirement of the F111 without a replacement to come online for a period of at least two and perhaps five or six years, resulting for the first time ever in our history in a situation where Australia will no longer have air superiority in our region. In the newspapers today we see further alarming evidence of that problem. There are articles in a couple of papers with headlines, such as ‘War plane bill goes sky high’ in the Herald Sun, referring to the JSF aircraft which the government have all but announced will be the replacement for the F111. The newspaper article refers to a report conducted by the United States Government Accountability Office, which did a review of the JSF program, which you might recall we signed up to without any process of evaluation. Mind-boggling though it seems, the single most important defence acquisition this country will make in the next 20 years-the replacement for our air strike capability-is being entered into without any of the normal processes of evaluation being undertaken. Compounding this problem, none of those processes have been followed. The report released this month by the US Government Accountability Office is scathing in its commentary on the JSF. This is what it says in part: JSF’s original business case, established when the program began in 1996, is unexecutable. Unexecutable-a damning indictment that puts beyond any doubt the question as to whether or not we have signed up to something that is deliverable. The United States Government Accountability Office have made it plain that the program planned from 1996 is now unexecutable. They identified a few of the reasons, and they are alarming. The cost estimate to develop the aircraft has increased 80 per cent. The government have been talking about the cost of each aircraft being around $67 million. I wonder whether the minister and the government are now factoring in an 80 per cent increase on that, or are we just going to have 80 per cent fewer aircraft when they finally arrive somewhere closer to 2015-five years after we give up the F111s? But that is not the only problem. As the United States Government Accountability Office report notes: ... operational capability has been pushed out 2 yearsMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Bevis (Brisbane) (11.50 A.m.)
theText: On many occasions in this parliament and in the parThat means that at this point in time everything will be delayed at the other end of the tunnel by at least two years. Of course, as we get closer to that point, it is more than likely that that two-year delay will be extended, which is not uncommon in high-tech, new projects of this kind, but which was totally unplanned for by this government when it decided to bring forward the retirement of the F111s from the anticipated date of 2020 to the new date of 2010. The US Government Accountability Office also noted: ... and expected acquisition quantitiesthat is, how many of these planes are going to be boughthave been cut by 535 aircraft. So from the time they started this program in 1996-and we signed up to it about two years ago-to now, they have themselves in a situation where the cost overruns have gone through the roof, with an 80 per cent increase. They are now looking at a minimum two-year delay and, on top of that, they now look like they are going to sell 535 fewer aircraft than they thought they would at the start. That is on a downward slope because some of the variants of the aircraft, such as the vertical take-off aircraft, have actually run into a weight of problems. Vertical take-off aircraft cannot carry the weapons and vertically take off at the same time, so they have a choice: whether or not they will leave the weapons at home or reduce the weight of the aircraft. This is a fiasco in the most critical area of defence capability this country will confront in the next 20 years. I argued long and hard in the last parliament, in the defence committee, to get a proper evaluation of this done and it was all uphill. Finally though, we did get a recommendation from the defence committee from the last parliament that recommended: … at the start of the next Parliament, the Minister for Defence requests the committee to conduct an inquiry into the ability of the Australian Defence Force to maintain air superiority in our region to 2020. It is time the government did it. Instead of playing games and waiting until after 30 June when they can control the show absolutely, that inquiry should start now. (Time expired) Leukaemia Foundation has come very close to home. One of my staff members has recently been diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia. He is a passionate Liberal member, a loyal friend, a long-time colleague and an outstanding and long-serving member of my staff. I have been overwhelmed at the support from everyone, and he and his family are truly grateful for the many messages, letters and cards of encouragement he has received. He will shortly undergo another bone marrow biopsy and he has completed his first treatment of chemotherapy. He has had quite a few rough days, but thankfully seems to be improving health wise. We can only hope and pray for his speedy recovery. I have been in regular contact with him and his family as he goes through this difficult time. Australia’s focus has shifted to this disease as this week is the Leukaemia Foundation’s World’s Greatest Shave for a Cure. This is the Leukaemia Foundation’s major fundraiser for the year. The World’s Greatest Shave is one of Australia’s premier charity events, and last year it raised $8.5 million. The Leukaemia Foundation funds groundbreaking research into better treatments and cures for leukaemia, lymphoma and myeloma. Its national research program has committed $3 million in the current financial year. This type of research, and the research MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mrs Draper (Makin) (11.56 A.m.)
theText: I rise to speak today on an issue that, unfortunately,that has gone before it, has had a dramatic effect on the treatments that are used for leukaemia and this has meant that leukaemia is not the life sentence that it once was. Better treatments have meant that survival rates have increased greatly. For example, children with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia now have an 80 per cent chance of survival, compared with a 30 per cent chance 20 years ago. This important fundraiser also provides funds for care and support services for sufferers and their families from the Leukaemia Foundation. They provide a free home away from home service for patients and their families. This is done in 16 accommodation centres located close to treatment facilities across Australia. Undoubtedly, many of my rural colleagues would know constituents who have come to need this invaluable service. The foundation also provides other very important services for leukaemia sufferers and their families-including support and counselling, education programs, transport to and from hospital, and practical assistance-all free of charge. I have great pleasure in reporting that two of my staff members have volunteered to have their heads shaved as part of the fundraising commitment during the World’s Greatest Shave as their way of chipping in for a mate and showing support as he continues his battle with leukaemia. It has also come to my attention that a number of my colleagues are also involved in this magnificent fundraising venture. I have been informed that the newly-elected member for Kingston is going to dye his hair-Liberal blue, he tells me-for this very special occasion. I hope that my constituents in Makin will forgive me for having purple hair, for a week or two at least, as I am also raising funds for the Leukaemia Foundation. I would like to encourage all members and staff, and all Australians across the nation, to contribute to this magnificent fundraising venture as the money raised has a very real benefit for a number of Australians every year, not least my staff member. Child Support Ms BIRD (Cunningham) (11.59 a.m.)-RecentlyI worked with the Child Support Agency to hold an information evening for constituents in my electorate who were either making or receiving child support payments. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the staff of the Child Support Agency for organising the evening. I know that those who attended found it as useful as I did. I am sure that all members of this parliament would be aware of the concerns of their own constituents who are involved in the child support system and those concerns were made clear to me at this information night. I attended the session with the express purpose of gaining a greater appreciation of the issues faced by parents who are involved in the child support system and in this I was successful. I went to listen to their concerns, to try and understand the pressures that everyone involved faces and to allow me to make a more informed contribution to debates about changes to the child support system after the Ministerial Taskforce on Child Support and Reference Group reports back later this month. There are some serious concerns about how Australia’s child support system operates. There are concerns about how the amount of child support payment is calculated and concerns about equity in the system. It would be easy for me to have dismissed concerns about the level of payments as the grumblings of disgruntled individuals forced to make payments but this was clearly not the case. MAIN COMMITTEE When the Child Support Scheme was established in 1988, its objective was to introduce and administer a system that shared the cost of supporting children between separated parents according to their capacity, and to make sure that adequate support is available for all children not living with both parents-a noble objective and one with which I cannot disagree, nor for that matter could the 100 or so people who came to the information session in Wollongong. There was a sense of common purpose among those assembled. Even though they might not agree with the detail of the system or the fact, indeed, that they are involved in it at all, they knew they were there and involved for the benefit of their children. Everyone assembled agreed that no matter the nature of the relationship between the now separated parents, they wanted the best for their kids. None of them wanted their kids to miss out on anything in life just because, for whatever reason, their relationship did not work. The other common purpose I noted was that both payers and recipients were keen to see the detail of the task force’s recommendations and anxious about the future of child support. The biggest concern related to the calculation of child support payments. Both payers and payees expressed this concern to me. The now separated parents, their new partners and other concerned relatives, such as grandparents, expressed their deeply held concerns that the current method of calculation created a particularly onerous payment regime that seemed to be based on a presumption that the lives of the individuals involved do not change from the time immediately after the relationship fails. That is, it does not seem to accommodate the separated partners moving on with their lives. It does not seem to reflect that the separated parents may find a new partner, may have more children or may find themselves in circumstances not foreseen at the time of separation. It is from this presumption that their concerns about the calculation of payment levels arise. While sitting with individuals discussing their particular circumstances, the constant refrain I heard, from both men and women, I hasten to add, is that payments made using the current formula left them with very little to live on. In fact, this led to some people informing me that they felt they were in a better position not to work than to continue to work. Some had considered taking second jobs or doing additional overtime to assist with the payments, but the calculation of payments based on gross income rather than net income, in conjunction with the current tax regime, would not have allowed them to get ahead anyway so they felt that was hardly worth their while. While the payment levels were hurting them, putting pressure on new relationships and in some cases leaving the children of these new relationships at a disadvantage, none of them expressed to me a desire to stop the payments for the children of their former relationship. We face a difficult task in reaching a workable solution to the problems of the child support system. It would be easy to dismiss their concerns as grumbling, but it is not. I look forward to examining the findings of the ministerial task force. I know that I am not alone in this, many in my electorate and in the electorates of others are looking forward to it. I urge the government to expedite the process of the task force recommendations. Newcastle Knights of the Newcastle Herald is the headline ‘$2 million penalty’. As most members would be aware, a few of weeks ago a couple of the young Newcastle Knights players, after playing a trial match at Bathurst, decided to embrace alcohol and then visit a dormitory at the univerMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Baldwin (Paterson) (12.05 P.m.)
theText: TodayI am not surprised that on the front pagesity, where indecent acts were performed on some women. As a result, one of the players, Dane Tilse-now an ex-player-was dismissed from the Newcastle Knights. Following that, the potential sponsor of the Newcastle Knights, Gizmondo-an American company who were to provide $700,000 per annum to the club-have withdrawn their support. Their logo will not be on the front of the club’s football jersey this year. This has left the Newcastle Knights in a precarious position. The team were fined some $100,000 because of their actions and are subject to a $100,000 suspended payment should anything else happen. As a person who supports the Newcastle Knights, I find their behaviour rather distasteful, particularly after the actions of the Canterbury Bulldogs last year when several players at Coffs Harbour were involved in what was alleged to be a gang rape of a female. This latest incident is more distasteful because this week, on 8 March, we celebrated International Women’s Day. One of the problems we have is that these young fellows, who have a bit of brilliant talent in football, in a lot of instances come from relatively disadvantaged backgrounds. They are brought into the high levels of league and, all of a sudden, they start to taste fame and fortune. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, can I say this and say it very clearly: no person, whether they be a footballer or ordinary member of the community-no matter what their role is in the community-should believe they have the liberty to do as they wish to any other member of the community, in particular women. I find this incident involving the Knights particularly distasteful. I can understand why the young lady involved in the incident has decided not to press on with the matter. To have to go through the process of court cases in pursuing these people would be very daunting, embarrassing and could cause long-term mental scarring. I witnessed this recently in relation to a case in Sydney, involving a young girl who was gang raped. The foolish actions of one of the jurors who decided on their own account to make an inspection of the crime scene led to some of the charges being appealed. The very severe sentences that were justifiably placed on the young men involved in the rape were overturned. The Crown wanted to conduct a new trial, but the young woman was not prepared to subject herself to another trial. I do not know what the footballers are like in other states; I only know that in New South Wales we have had two very distasteful incidents involving footballers who think they are above the law and the rest of the community. Because of the actions of not just Dane Tilse but also others who were there with him, the fans of the Newcastle Knights will suffer. The other hard-working, hard-playing and decent fine men who make up the Newcastle Knights will suffer. They are the only team in the NRL that will start the competition without a major sponsor. They will be the only team that runs onto the paddock without a name on their jersey. We have some great players in the Newcastle Knights, some very respected members of the community who know how to handle themselves and who have been able to handle the fame and fortune that has come their way. But, as I said, I find it extremely distasteful, particularly as a parent of a young daughter who enjoys her football, to see young men act as though they are above the law and bring great embarrassment upon the great game of football and our community, Newcastle. MAIN COMMITTEE Australian Institute of Sport Awards sporting field, as part of my responsibility as shadow minister for sport and recreation. I had the great pleasure yesterday to attend the Australian Institute of Sport athlete and coach awards at the AIS theatrette. It was a good occasion, where you saw the very cream of Australian sporting talent represented, from the organisational level to the coaching level to the athletes from both the Olympic team and the Paralympic team. You got a real sense of the esprit de corps of the athletes and the community that makes up that sporting group. You got a real feel that there is a sense of purpose and plenty of competition among all and sundry, both within and across sports, but also a good deal of camaraderie, which has been shown most strongly by the sorts of results that have been achieved in recent times. A selection of awards were made. A number of scholarships and educational and vocational awards were made to a range of particularly younger athletes, and to them go my congratulations. The main awards, I think, really showed just how well Australian sport has been going. The AIS Athlete of the Year Award was shared between Ryan Bailey and Petria Thomas. Members do not need to be reminded that Petria is a great swimmer who won some three gold medals at the Athens Olympics, in the 100 metres butterfly, the 4 x 100 metres freestyle relay and the 4 x 100 metres medley relay. Ryan, of course, is the most laconic and engaging cyclist who won gold in the sprint and in the keirin on the track in Athens, and was later named Cycling Australia’s 2004 Cyclist of the Year. Both of them have been great ambassadors for Australian sport and have achieved a lot over their careers and certainly, although I think Petria is retiring, it may well be that from Ryan his best is yet to come. There were other awards. The AIS Program of the Year went to diving. This is the second year in a row that diving has been given that award and it goes to show just what a great effort diving has been putting in over the last several years. At the Athens Olympics the divers produced their best effort ever, with one gold, one silver and six bronze medals. In particular, who could forget Chantelle Newbery, who became the first Australian diver in some 60 years to win Olympic gold in the 10-metre platform event. The AIS Junior Athlete of the Year was archer Tim Cuddihy. I am sure we all remember that Tim won a bronze medal at the Athens Olympics. It was an outstanding performance. I think it is true to say that it was a bit unexpected in terms of some of the public comment at the time, but Tim equalled the Olympic record for a 12-arrow match at 115, and broke the Olympic record for the highest cumulative score for a finals series, shooting a total of 340 over his three matches. Tim himself is only a kid and he has a long way to go, but his achievements so far have been phenomenal. The AIS Team of the Year was men’s hockey. Like many members, I am sure, I have watched the Kookaburras over the years and they have come close so many times in the Olympics. They previously had lost three Olympic finals. After making it to the semifinals and beyond in eight of their last nine appearances at the summer games since Tokyo in 1964, this is the first time they have gone that extra yard and won the gold medal. It was a fitting tribute to them to receive this particular award. The award for the Coach of the Year went to Martin Barras, from cycling. People will recall that the cycling team at the Athens Olympics was again the most successful on record, with an incredible five gold medals, two silver and two bronze. It is certain that Martin has played an important role in building the team and giving it the capacity to be able to do that. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Griffin (Bruce) (12.10 P.m.)
theText: I rise today to talk about some recent events on theCycling had a very difficult time with drug allegations last year so it has been a tough time for cycling, but they really came through in Athens and certainly Martin was an important part of that. To all those involved in the awards-to those who made the finals, to those who were under consideration, to those who won-congratulations on a great effort. To all those responsible for the administration from the ASC and the AIS: congratulations on jobs well done. It certainly has been a premier time for Australian sport. The job is there now to try and maintain it, and I wish them all the very best in trying to achieve that in the future. Indian Ocean Tsunami property during the Boxing Day tsunami. As Secretary of the Sri Lankan Parliamentary Friendship GroupI visited Sri Lanka recently. I must say I was shocked at the devastation I saw throughout the country. On a good note, Australia’s aid was delivered very quickly. It was the sort of aid that was required, and when I spoke to a number of people in the parliament and in business they singled out Australia’s response as being appropriate and on time. Other countries, of course, sought to assist Sri Lanka. Some countries sent the wrong sort of help, but I want to congratulate the Australian High Commissioner, Dr Greg French, and the staff at the Australian High Commission for the excellent job that they have done in assisting the rebuilding of Sri Lanka and, indeed, in aiding those people who were so grievously affected by the tragedy. I was also impressed by the many private efforts being carried out by various groups in Australia and elsewhere raising money here to assist local communities in Sri Lanka. I think all of us get a bit concerned about the cost of administration of some of the large charities. I am not going to single any out, because they all do very good work, but clearly it costs a large amount of money to run a global charity and people, at times, are a little reluctant to contribute to what they largely see as being administration expenses. I saw quite a number of Australians, New Zealanders, Britons and people from Europe who had gone to Sri Lanka to assist in a private capacity. At Arugam Bay in particular, a place that was totally devastated, there were many overseas organisations raising money privately and working very hard on the ground to repair infrastructure. I assisted to reconstruct a shed. the wrong way and had to take it down again. As a person who can barely hammer in a nail, it was great to be able to help in that small way. Here in Australia, Petrea King, who has done wonderful work with cancer victims, has sent her son, Simon Vandervoort, to Sri Lanka, and they were endeavouring to assist the children of that country. In my own electorate of Fisher, while I was away there was a cocktail party held to rebuild Kumari, a village just 14 kilometres from Arugam Bay. I want to congratulate Raelene Boyle, Alfie and Janine Langer, Errol and Rohina Johnston-they live six months in Sri Lanka and six months on the Sunshine Coast, Rohina being Sri Lankan-Judy Wild, Sally Waterworth, Nick Bevacqua, Dr Ellen Mowatt, Jeni Hing, Julie Dickson, Jennifer Anderson and William Darby for sponsoring this cocktail party, which raised $150,000 towards the work of rebuilding that particular community. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (12.15 P.m.)
theText: I think all of us were appalled at the loss of life and
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Baldwin
theText: Is it still standing?
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: I hope it is still standing. It was made of mango wood. I put a wall up inThe Speaker of the Sri Lankan parliament, when I spoke to him, praised Australia’s efforts. I was also privileged to meet the Deputy Chairman of Committees of the parliament, the Secretary of the Sri Lanka-Australia Parliamentary Friendship Association and a number of ministers and former ministers as well as captains of industry who head the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce. Universally, there was praise for Australia’s efforts. At times we do hear bad stories. For instance, there was an American organisation that decided to provide toilet paper for people in Arugam Bay. In that particular area toilet paper is not generally used. The organisation imported toilet paper from the United States at a cost of $US10 per roll and the children were using it as streamers. Happily, that is not happening with Australian charities. What they are doing is looking at where the needs are and making sure that the money gets through to the people. Australia’s response was excellent. As a government, we have done the right thing, and I thank the opposition for their support of the government’s initiatives in this area. Individually we have helped, and also importantly Christian and other community groups are assisting people in Sri Lanka. For instance, Anglican Aid Abroad in Brisbane is assisting the Anglican Sisters of St Margaret, who have an orphanage. The people to people links and the help which has been given will bring our two countries even closer together while making a very important material improvement to the future of the devastated areas of Sri Lanka. Economy strong for so long by so many so quickly be considered to have cracked with only a smallsome might even say tiny-interest rate rise of 25 basis points? Any economy that experiences a rate rise of only a quarter of a per cent should have an equally measured response, so why have business, industry, households and the majority of Australians been so affected by this rate rise, and why are they all so worried about its impact? Economic data released last week now reveals that the economy began to slow late last year and, with a further rate rise expected in the near future, the impact of higher interest rates could be more profound than understood by government. This is especially alarming for an administration that has failed to inoculate the economy against an overzealous election campaign spending spree of $66 billion in 20 weeks. John Howard and Peter Costello must have known for months, if not years, prior to the 2004 election that an economy based on rampant consumerism could not be sustained. But, instead of applying the brakes, the Treasurer and Prime Minister firmly jumped on the accelerator and fuelled consumption merely to purchase their way back into office. There is no doubt that the Australian economy has performed well in recent years. Australians have enjoyed 14 consecutive years of growth, which is largely the result of the reforms undertaken by the Hawke and Keating Labor governments. This trend, however, will not continue if the current neglect of and disregard for the basic premise of economic sustainability is ignored by the Howard government. Economic data and reports are awash with details of squandered opportunity and complacency by John Howard and Peter Costello. The Reserve Bank of Australia, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the International Monetary Fund, the Business Council of Australia, the head of Treasury, government departments, industry leaders and many others have all warned about a stalling economy. In particular, they have all lamented the opportunities lost through a failure of the Howard govMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (12.20 P.m.)
theText: How can an economy that has been heralded as soernment to reinvest in the economy and the nation’s infrastructure. Not only has the coalition lacked the vision and foresight needed to deal with a 21st century economy but also it has lacked the determination to deal with an emerging infrastructure crisis that has the potential to derail our productivity, an event from which we may need years to recover. The last 20 years were undoubtedly about economic reform and the next 20 years undoubtedly need to be about infrastructure reform and productivity gains. So whether it is the interest rate rise, the massive trade deficit, the massive skill shortages or the emerging infrastructure crisis, the economy is unravelling at an alarming pace. But of all of these the most worrying sign for the economy, and families, is the high levels of personal debt. Several reports now show that the average household debt servicing ratio is much higher than it was when interest rates hit 17 per cent in the 1990s. This is a figure that the government should pay close attention to, looking at it with serious concern. Families are now using more of their disposable income to service debt with interest rates at seven per cent than they did when interest rates were at 17 per cent. So badly has debt spiralled out of control that the smallest shift in interest rates in today’s terms represents a massive and unbearable pressure on consumers. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment fell sharply from February to March this year, with survey data gathered over the weekend showing a record 16.6 per cent fall in sentiment, the biggest fall ever recorded in the history of the survey. Among mortgagees there was an astonishing 20.2 per cent fall in confidence. This dramatic fall in sentiment can be explained by very high levels of household debt, which make families even more vulnerable to the smallest upward movements in interest rates. But the real crunch will not be felt most painfully by those with high mortgage payments. While those will certainly hurt them, the tipping point and the straw that will eventually break the camel’s back will be the added burden of extra payments on credit cards at rates of 20 per cent and more. The economy, like a sleeping giant awoken from its sleep, has reacted badly, and we may yet see the full impact of the Howard-Costello government’s economic mismanagement. While this government has crowed for many years about how credible its economic management is, how good it is and how it is the economic genius, we are now seeing the real picture. It is not painted by rhetoric from the Labor Party; it is confirmed by the Reserve Bank of Australia, by the head of Treasury, by government departments, by the IMF and by the OECD. These are the real credible voices on what is happening to our economy. I regret that this government is not yet capable of doing something about it. Iraq lives concerning ourselves with the small things like what to cook for dinner, getting the laundry done, dodging the traffic and getting to work on time. Occasionally we experience something that makes us stop and look at the bigger picture. I had one of those experiences some weeks ago as I observed Iraqi people taking their lives in their hands to vote. For so long they have been living under a feudal yoke, having absolutely no say in how their lives were run. They came out of their homes and risked death to cast their votes as a final rebuttal to the regime of Saddam Hussein and his acolytes. In some Western democracies people can vote but do not have to, so they often cannot be bothered to take part. In Australia we can vote and we have to vote-and thank God we can. We all hear complaints from people who resent having to do so. Yet in Iraq, in spite of all the threats, the bombings and the chaos-or maybe because MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mrs Gash (Gilmore) (12.25 P.m.)
theText: Usually we in the Western world go about our dailyof them-the people showed that they wanted to play a role in their country’s future. They wanted this democracy badly enough to risk their lives to vote in Iraq’s first free election. As one of those who voted here in this House to send troops into Iraq, I wanted to go and support the military and other personnel from my electorate to show them that I, too, was prepared to take some risks. But when I heard that 120 people were directly engaged in protecting just two Australian electoral officials, it seemed ludicrous to take even more people from the job at hand. In the end, I could not get into Iraq to observe the elections but observed proceedings at election booths outposted along the Jordan-Iraq border, from the Jordanian side. It made me proud knowing that Australia had helped make this election possible. And it made me proud that our military personnel, diplomats, election officials and many others had contributed to this success. In fact, people on the streets told me how they enjoyed the Australians’ professional but more relaxed attitude and appreciated their cultural sensitivity. We all know that this election is just a first step and there is a long way to go and that the system is not perfect. Australia’s own system has been operating for over 100 years and it is not perfect either. In the streets of JordanI went out and met many Iraqis who came there to vote and asked about their feelings. The people voting told me that they were joyful, thankful and happy to have the opportunity to vote and, more than that, they have now regained hope. Imagine what life without hope must have been like. They told me, too, about the wonderful things happening already in Iraq since the occupation: schools reopening and the huge building programs under way. Iraqi people are being trained to look after themselves. I spoke with many people and heard many things that I have not seen reported on TV or in the newspapers over the last year or two. I guess good news does not sell as well as bad news. We have been shown plenty of the horror of war but little or none of the happiness or hope that freedom from tyranny has brought. There is so much good news out there that Australians are not being told. I call upon the media to give all sides of the story for a change. Why is it that the good news is being censored? Why do we only hear of the bombs and deaths? Why did they not report such things as the wonderful international effort that was displayed to make these elections successful? These efforts deserve special commendation. My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and his department have been just fantastic. They saw to my arrangements and gave me every opportunity to learn as much as possible in quite difficult circumstances. The department of foreign affairs personnel are extremely professional and knowledgeable, yet can communicate easily with people from all walks of life-from royalty to MPs like me with very different backgrounds. I record my thanks to the Australian Ambassador to Jordan, John Tileman, and his first secretary, Helen Smith, who ensured that I met the relevant people and could have my questions answered. They made a difficult trip much more worthwhile. I must also record my thanks to the men and women of HMAS Albatross from my electorate who, as usual, are providing excellent services to others on behalf of our country. I can certainly assure their families and the people of Gilmore that their efforts are not in vain. It is almost impossible to relate just how the Iraqi people feel about our Australian men and women, and I am immensely proud of them. I am humbled but grateful that we in this House, from all sides, are blessed with the honour of representing constituents in the best democracy in the world. MAIN COMMITTEE Collaborative and Innovative Responses for Youth at Risk Ms LIVERMORE (Capricornia) (12.29 p.m.)-TodayI wish to support a fantastic program, the Collaborative and Innovative Responses for Youth at Risk program, otherwise known as CIRYAR. I know that the member for Hinkler, who is sitting opposite, has also been very supportive of this program. I may be calling on him again to help us out because, once again, the program is facing closure as its funding will run out towards the middle of this year. It provides a service to young people and their families who are dealing with issues of youth suicide and self-harm. CIRYAR was started in 2003 as a 12-month pilot program funded by the Department of Family and Community Services. In my remarks today I should say that it has had a bit of a chequered history with the federal government. The federal government provided the initial funding, which was great, but, because it was only a 12-month pilot program, the funding finished just when the program had established itself and established its significance in providing services to a really crucial and distinct group of people in the Rockhampton community. Getting the program refunded by the government has been an ongoing battle ever since. When CIRYAR started out, its aim was to establish a service that provides professional support to young people and their families with complex mental health and/or social isolation issues or support needs. There is no doubt that the team at CIRYAR have achieved all of that and more. This program has been embraced by the community of Rockhampton because it has helped so many of our young people and their families who knew that it was literally a lifeline that they clung to when they reached crisis point. The program originated in response to community concerns about urgent and serious gaps in health, education and welfare services for young people with mental illness or significant mental health issues. It is now also recognised as filling a significant gap by providing support to the many young people who do not have any diagnosed mental health problem but who are finding it difficult to cope with the pressures that come with being a teenager-bullying, peer pressure, relationships, family conflict and stress associated with their academic performance. through a range of responses, including crisis intervention and activities to build resilience in young people and greater capacity in the broader community to understand and help young people when they are struggling. There are things like crisis management, personal support, counselling and psychotherapy, education about mental health and key youth issues, personal growth and skills development opportunities, collaborative case management, and information, advocacy and referral services for young people. As I said, CIRYAR has been embraced by our local community in a way I have never seen before. It is something that the Rockhampton community can be very proud of. When the pilot funding ran out at the end of 2003, the community rallied around at all levels to fight to keep the program going. In the circumstances, how could we not do that? For some families, it was what was keeping their kids going. A campaign run primarily by one of our local radio stations raised $70,000 from the community to help keep the program going, and other media outlets have also gotten involved. There is a business group or a group of community and business leaders who got together and MAIN COMMITTEE who meet regularly to see how they can support CIRYAR. And, of course, those involved in youth work in our community are constantly out there supporting CIRYAR and reinforcing the fact that it plays a very significant role in filling a gap in services for young people who may not have a recognised mental health disorder but who nonetheless need that extra help to cope with life. I have here a pile of testimonials and letters of support. It is as long as your arm. Many are from government agencies-both Commonwealth and state government agencies-who refer young people to CIRYAR for help. There is also a letter from the mother of a young girl. time is coming once again for CIRYAR. We have to get behind it. The federal government needs to play its role in keeping this important service going for the young people of Rockhampton. (Time expired) Royal Visit Technical College Infrastructure Development Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) (12.35 p.m.)-Last night I had the delightful pleasure of meeting the Danish royal couple, Princess Mary and Prince Frederik. It was a personal pleasure. My brother quite frequently sees me meeting all these wonderful people in the media coverage or in the media clippings that my mother sends him. As an Australian living in Denmark, he is married to a Danish citizen and is raising his three children as Danes-I suppose he did what Princess Mary has done but he did it 15 years ago. When he had the opportunity, and knowing the role that I play in Australian society, he sent me an email from Denmark with a photo of him and Princess Mary together. SoI am going to take great delight in sending back to yet another Australian abroad the news that the royal couple have been welcomed very warmly over here, as warmly as Richard has been welcomed into Denmark. I have three older brothers, so I suppose I had more of a tomboy upbringing, but I do have a five-year old princess. She is very pretty in pink and she dreams of being a princess. It is quite delightful that I now do not have to disabuse her of her dream and tell her that as an Australian she is never going to be a princess! I can quite honestly say, ‘Keep dreaming, my dear; you can carry on wearing that tiara and carrying your pretty wand.’ The royal couple have had an extraordinarily successful visit. As my colleague reminded me, I am a republican, but on this occasion it was very sweet to see a couple in love. I would also like to make a report on Penrith’s progress towards our tender for a technical college, which will increase the number of young people completing trades in my area. My area has a high number of tradespeople. It has a highly motivated parental work force that makes sure that kids get through those difficult first and second years of study before they start earning the income that makes it easier for them to attend to various aspects of working in trades. We have a tremendous amount of support from tradesmen and tradeswomen in our area for that technical college. One aspect of the constraints facing construction in Australia at the moment is the escalation in raw material costs. We also have record low unemployment levels, which makes it very hard to find unskilled labour as well as skilled labour. There are shortages of labour right across Western Sydney. We also need to be doing more to make child MAIN COMMITTEE care available, to bring females into the work force, to retain people longer and all those sorts of issues in the lead-up to the next budget. Those issues really rely on town planning being done properly so that the built environment in which women are trying to manage a family, schooling and child-care options as well as their work actually functions. A critical part of that infrastructure will be the Army land in north Penrith. That is an area that could provide over 5,000 jobs and possibly more in the long term and would allow females to work close to home and create some balance between raising their family, obligations with schooling, after school work within the home and paid employment. That positioning of jobs close to the people who we want to retain in the work force is critical to addressing some of these skills shortages. Certainly, if you add one or two hours commuting time, I think most mothers in a single income, single parent family-unless income is critical-will decline that option because it is preferable to be working closer to home. We need to put in infrastructure such as extending the M2. There are a radical number of houses being constructed in the Penrith Lakes area and between Bligh Park and Werrington. An enormous number of houses are coming into existence. Over the long term we need to extend the M2 from the Western Sydney orbital interchange in the area of my colleague from Blacktown right out to the Northern Road and make it part of that major infrastructure that links Sydney. With these ideas in mind I think we can continue with some of the more realistic dreams that young Australian women have. (Time expired) Indian Ocean Tsunami speak on the tsunami and the devastation which swept across many countries-Burma, the Seychelles, the Maldives, Somalia, Malaysia, Thailand, southern India, Sri Lanka and, in particular, Indonesia. The final death toll was 300,000, including 230,000 in Aceh, Indonesia. Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced; in Aceh, the figure is around 400,000. These statistics do not convey the reality of the extent of loss and suffering that will go on for some time. Families have lost husbands, wives, children and grandparents. The tsunami has had a devastating impact. I have previously complimented the government on its response to the tsunami. I am aware that an appropriation bill dealing with financial assistance has gone through the House and there has been debate on a motion on the tsunami disaster, but I am happy to place on the record again my support for the government’s actions in response to the tsunami. I have also mentioned that the fine work and generosity of the Australian government on behalf of all of us has only been exceeded by the generosity of the Australian people: men, women and children-and I especially compliment the children. Australians have donated more than $190 million to 29 different aid agencies that are signatories to the Australian Council for International Development Code of Conduct. The tsunami has swept our concern for mankind to the fore. We have made every effort to preserve and perpetuate it. There is no doubt that on 16 January, the day that we officially commemorated the tsunami, people from around the world understood that when humanity is to the fore it will strike a common chord in people in Australia, in Indonesia and in every other country in the world. This has been such an exceptional event that we should not lose that sense of humanity and that sense of caring for one another. It is for that reason that I propose to write to the Prime MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Price (Chifley) (12.40 P.m.)
theText: I want to take the opportunity of the adjournment toMinister. January 16 should be marked as a national day of giving for humanity, a day for us to remember the victims of all disasters, natural and man-made. I am conscious that around that time we had the Adelaide bushfires. A day of giving would be a reminder of the generosity of spirit that we are capable of as ordinary people, whether parents or children. Out of the tsunami, out of the government’s response and out of the response of individual people of Australia much good has come; there has been great generosity. Let us not lose that spirit when we are faced with another tragedy or another disaster. Let us have another day of giving, 16 January, so that people can respond and generously donate to alleviate the suffering and poverty of others on this planet. We are all God’s children on the planet, whether we are black, brown, brindle or white and whether we are Christian, Muslim, Jewish, Buddhist, Hindu or whatever-and 16 January ought to be a day for remembering that. It ought to be a day when we reach out, in the global village, and give a dollar or two to help someone else. Science Meets Parliament Day Indoor Air Pollution the very successful program Science Meets Parliament. Certainly it is a great opportunity for members of parliament to meet with scientists and members of the scientific community, and I certainly welcomed the opportunity during the week to meet with Len Ferrari, a scientist from my electorate; Marianne Johnson, who is from the Victorian Institute for Chemical Sciences; and Professor Andrew Bolton, from the University of New England, who has done a lot of great work in relation to Rivercare. Rivercare and the issues of the marine and riparian environments on the coast are vitally important because of the great pressures that are placed upon that environment by very rapid development. I think all members of this House would have appreciated the opportunity to meet with the many highly qualified members of the science community who made their time available to communicate to us the many things that science is achieving and the needs of science within our community today. As a nation we cannot put enough emphasis on the importance of science and I think that as a nation we are going to derive great benefits from science. SoI would like to commend the Science Meets Parliament program specifically. I think it is a great initiative and one that should be strongly supported in the future. From the interviews that I had with these scientists one point of particular interest to me was the study that Mr Ferrari conducted in partnership with Mr Frank Fleer, Ted Pender and Mark Tulau. That study focused on the issue of indoor air pollution. It was a study conducted in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra and it was done in some 116 homes and looked at the impact of the polluting effect of non-flued gas heaters. We focus very much in this country on outdoor air quality standards, but we have had a much lesser focus on the issue of indoor air quality. It was very interesting to note that this study concentrated on the presence of chemicals such as nitrogen dioxide, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and formaldehyde and took into account a whole range of issues such as the outside air conditions, in addition to the levels of rates of ventilation that existed in the homes involved. It took into account very old homes, some of them around 100 years old, right up to more modern homes. It covered a range of heating appliances, both old and new designs. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Ciryar Was Able To Change That Girl S Life And Give Her Some Hope For The Future Crunch

speaker: Mr Hartsuyker (Cowper) (12.45 P.m.)
theText: I rise in the Main Committee to speak onThe findings of this report really are quite disturbing. Let us take nitrogen dioxide, for instance. When one looks at the typical types of concentrations that were recorded in the outside air-and I would like to quote a couple here-one finds that the maximum concentrations of nitrogen dioxide in New South Wales are around 86 parts per billion. But when one looks at the research one finds that the level of nitrogen dioxide in an indoor situation where these heaters were present was some 930 parts per billion, over 10 times the concentrations of the pollutants existent in the outside air. The study found, and its conclusions were disturbing, that the concentrations of nitrogen dioxide were 10 times higher than in the outside air and that these levels are far above World Health Organisation recommendations. The study also found that there were significant levels of other pollutants in the air. So it is a cause for great concern that we have been focusing very much on outside air quality, yet we have this potential problem with the impact of non-flued gas heaters on inside air quality. In fact, the Western Australian health minister, Jim McGinty, said that the state government considers the levels of indoor pollution to be ‘a serious health risk’. That is most interesting. In many of our schools we have non-flued gas heaters, and one of the things that nitrogen dioxide does is cause breathing difficulties. It has been identified as a potential source of asthmatic complaints in young children. We have many school buildings around our country being warmed by non-flued gas heaters. This study shows that there is a very significant rise in the presence of pollutants in the air through non-flued heaters, some 10 times that being encountered in normal air conditions. I think it is something that we need to look at very carefully. The Clean Air Society of Australia and New Zealand is very focused on this matter and has issued a number of press releases. We as a government should be mindful that we focus not only on outside air quality but also on indoor air quality as a very important determinant of health. Southern Family Life knowledge the work of a wonderful organisation in my electorate, Southern Family Life. I would like to highlight the excellent work they are doing in two programs in particular-a program called Creating Capable Communities and another, the Youthworx@Station Road program. For 30 years Southern Family Life have been working with the families in my local bayside community who are disadvantaged and at risk. They are an organisation totally committed to supporting families and the local community. The Creating Capable Communities program is based in the public housing estates and works with the residents to build relationships, friendships and supporting networks to foster a positive community atmosphere. I have met many of the participants-men, women and children-and the sense of community that is being developed is really special. Approximately 1,200 families reside in the public housing estates in and around my electorate. Many of these families and communities in the past have, to a greater or lesser extent, suffered from social isolation, financial disadvantage, mental health issues, violence and alcohol and drug use. Many of them have come from overseas-immigrants who do not have the confidence and the skills to interact with their fellow residents in these housing estates. It is a very sad and lonely situation for many of these people. Through social activities, such as playgroups and barbecues, and peer support groups, the Creating Capable Communities project is working on building a community environment where people can pull together and MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Ciryar Was Able To Change That Girl S Life And Give Her Some Hope For The Future Crunch

speaker: Mr Robb (Goldstein) (12.50 P.m.)
theText: I am privileged to have this opportunity today to accontribute to their community, so they feel like a community and are there to help and support each other. One of the several other programs run by Southern Family Life that I would like to commend is the Youthworx@Station Road program. Youthworx@Station Road is a retro and recycled clothing store established in early 2003. The shop provides young people with an eight-week opportunity to gain some work experience, which is vital to their being able to go on to find full-time work. The participants receive free on-the-job training in customer service and retail skills, free training in modules of the Certificate 11 in Retail Operations, personal coaching and mentoring and assistance with a job search. The greatest barrier for many of these kids in finding work is the lack of previous work experience, lack of a formal resume and no professional references. The Youthworx program gives young people an opportunity to gain some professional work experience and the step up they need to go on to find further work in the retail and other sectors. It is a wonderful thing to see these young people grow in confidence and self-esteem as a result of this program. It is a life-shaping experience. I have enormous admiration for those good and committed people who are making this happen at Southern Family Life. This organisation, Southern Family Life, has demonstrated over the past 30 years an extraordinary commitment to the bayside community. I have highlighted just two of its programs, but there are many more. I commend Southern Family Life to the House and thank the people involved in it, particularly Southern Family Life’s CEO, Jo Cavanagh, for their extraordinary commitment to our community. Main Committee adjourned at 12.55 p.m. MAIN COMMITTEE Strengthening Medicare Campaign (Question No. 36) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 November 2004: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 3583 (Hansard, 3 August 2004, page 31943), what sum has the Howard Government budgeted for its Strengthening Medicare campaign. (2) When will the evaluation of this campaign be completed. (3) When will the evaluation report be finalised and published. (1) A budget of $15 million was allocated for the Strengthening Medicare advertising campaign. (2) The evaluation of this campaign was completed and the evaluation report presented to my department in August 2004. (3) The evaluation report will help shape future government policy and, as such, would not normally be made public. Scullin Electorate: Family Payments (Question No. 106) Mr Jenkins asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 17 November 2004: (1) How many recipients of the Family Tax and Child Care benefit received letters of debt notification in relation to overpayment of those benefits in (a) 2002-2003, (b) 2003-2004, and (c) 2004-2005 in the electoral division of Scullin. (2) How many recipients of the Family Tax and Child Care benefit received letters of debt notification in relation to overpayment of those benefits in (a) 2002-2003, (b) 2003-2004, and (c) 2004-2005 in the postcode area (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083 (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089, (ix) 3090, (x) 3091 and (xi) 3752 ing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) and (2): The time and resources required for Centrelink to extract the number of letters is considered too costly to warrant proceeding with sourcing the data to answer these questions. Visiting Warships (Question No. 381) Mr Melham asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 9 December 2004: (1) What is the involvement of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) in radiation protection planning for visits to Australian ports by nuclear powered warships. (2) Which Australian ports have been the subject of a radiological assessment by ARPANSA (or the former Nuclear Safety Bureau) for visits by nuclear powered warships and when were those assessments undertaken and finalised.
title: Ciryar Was Able To Change That Girl S Life And Give Her Some Hope For The Future Crunch

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the follow
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) The Australia Government previously established an interdepartmental committee called the ‘Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) (VSP(N))’ to control arrangements for visits to Australia by nuclearpowered warships (NPW). ARPANSA provides two experts to VSP(N) and to its standing Technical Working Group, one for nuclear safety and one for radiation protection issues. Arrangements for visits are documented in the Department of Defence manual Visits by Nuclear Powered Warships to Australian Ports (OPSMAN1), Edition 7, 2002. The responsibilities for through ARPANSA, the Department of Health and Ageing is responsible for: provision of technical advice on all aspects of nuclear reactor safety matters; provision of technical advice on nuclear reactor accident modelling; assessment of the suitability of specific ports for visits by NPW against radiological criteria; and provision of advice on radiation monitoring proposals. participation in environmental radiation monitoring operations and performing analyses of samples as required; provision of thermoluminescent dosimeters to state authorities and RAN tug crews; participation with ANSTO in the initial compilation of summaries of radiation monitoring data; providing technical advisers as required; and having available back-up emergency monitoring equipment and personnel for use, if required, in the event of a reactor accident. In the event of a radiation emergency involving a nuclear powered warship, ARPANSA would undertake the role of Commonwealth Technical Advisor and provide advice on radiation protection to state and territory agencies. maintains an additional environmental monitoring capability that can be activated through Emergency Management Australia and the Commonwealth Disaster Response Plan in order to supplement state and territory resources and the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation radiation monitoring teams. (2) The ports that have been assessed and are approved for visits by nuclear powered warships are listed in the current edition of the OPSMAN1. Ports and their associated arrangements for visits are re-validated every two years by the Technical Working Group of the VSP(N). Port Validated for Validated for Radiological Last Validation submarine aircraft carrier Assessment Fremantle Yes Yes May 1996 March 2003 HMAS Stirling Yes No March 1996 March 2003 Albany Yes (1) No Information not Information available not available Melbourne Yes No February 1997 Oct 2004 Hobart Yes Yes September 1993 Oct 2003 Jervis Bay Yes (1) No Information not Feb 2004 available Brisbane Yes Yes August 1996 July 2004 Port Validated for Validated for Radiological Last Validation submarine aircraft carrier Assessment Gladstone Yes No May 1993 July 2004 Darwin Yes No March 1994 March 2003 (1) For special transient purposes only, such as emergency transfers of personnel. Tweed After Hours Clinic (Question No. 409) Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 9 December 2004: (1) Has planning for the Tweed After Hours clinic commenced; if so, (a) what is the planning process, and (b) how long will the process take; if not, when does the Government expect planning to commence. (2) Has he chosen a location for the Tweed After Hours clinic; if so, (a) what are the details, and (b) why was it chosen; if not, what is the Government doing to find a suitable location. (3) Has the Government had any discussions with the Tweed Hospital regarding arrangements for the Tweed After Hours clinic; if so, what are the details of those discussions; if not, when will he contact the Hospital regarding these arrangements. (4) What security measures have been or will be put in place to ensure the safety of patients and staff at the Tweed After Hours clinic. (5) How will the Tweed After Hours clinic be funded. (6) What sum will be provided annually to the Tweed After Hours clinic. (7) Will funding for the clinic be available in the next budget. During the 2004 Federal Election campaign the Government announced a number of targeted measures to help restore after hours GP services in metropolitan and regional Australia in the Election 2004 Policy– Round the Clock Medicare: Investing in After Hours GP Services. As part of this initiative in 2004-05 the Government will offer start-up grants of $200,000 for welllocated after hours clinics, run by local GPs, in Tweed Heads and four other specified locations. (1) (a) and (b) No specific planning has taken place in respect to the actual service to be established in Tweed Heads. There have, however been extensive discussions with local general practitioners and GP groups. The former Member for Richmond, the Hon Larry Anthony, was instrumental in facilitating these discussions. In January 2005, the Department of Health and Ageing (the ‘Department’) called for submissions for start-up grant funding from interested parties to establish after hours services in Tweed Heads and four other specified locations. The selection process for these grants is competitive and submissions will be assessed by a Departmental assessment committee. Start-up grant funding will be provided to the successful applicant(s) within the 2004-05 financial year. (2) No. (3) My Department has not had discussions with the Tweed Hospital. My Office had a conversation with the Chief Executive Officer of the Tweed Hospital following the Government’s decision not to support a co-located after hours clinic. The Hospital is welcome to have further discussions if it wishes. It could make an expression of interest in providing the after hours service under Round the Clock Medicare, or it could join a consortium with GPs or other providers, for assistance under Round the Clock Medicare.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) The security arrangements for the after hours service that will be implemented in Tweed Heads will be a matter for the service providers. (5) The successful start-up grant applicant in Tweed Heads will receive funding via a Funding Agreement with the Department. (6) Initially the Government will provide $200,000 in start up assistance for an after hours clinic in Tweed Heads. The clinic will be eligible to apply for recurrent assistance of up to $200,000 per year under other provisions of the Round the Clock Medicare initiative. (7) See answer to (6). Australian Customs Service (Question No. 447) writing, on 8 February 2005: Will the Minister Provide further details of the administered expenses (including third Party Outputs) incurred by the Australian Customs Service as reported on page 30 of its report for 2003-2004, in particular, (a) confirm that total actual administered expenses were $23,123,000 for the 2003-2004 reporting period, (b) what was the nature of each administered expense, and (c) for each administered expense, what was the difference, if any, between actual administered expense and the sum allocated for the administered expense in the 2003-2004 budget.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs, In
theText: the honourable member’s question: (a) the total actual administered expenses for the 2003-2004 reporting period were $23,123,000. (b) The nature of each administered expense was: (1) Receivables provision for doubtful debts $17,406,000 (2) Debts written off $5,469,000 (3) Contribution to World Customs Organisation $248,000 (c) There were no amounts allocated in the 2003-2004 budget for provision for doubtful debts nor debts written off. These expenses reflect a change in policy developed in consultation with the ANAO regarding the recognition and provisioning for prosecutions and fines. The World Customs Organisation was allocated $280,000 in the 2003-2004 budget; the final payment was influenced by prevailing foreign exchange rates. International Air Passengers (Question No. 451) writing, on 8 February 2005: (1) When did the Australian Customs Service (ACS) review the assumption of a ten minute delay between aircraft arrival and the time passengers arrive at the ECP queue for calculating the facilitation rate of international air passengers in Australian airports. (2) Will the Minister provide details of the formula and explain how it is used to calculate the facilitation rate. (3) Is the ACS able to apply the formula to the international air passengers facilitation rates reported in its report for 2003-2004; if not, why not; if so, what are the results of applying the formula. the honourable member’s question: (1) Customs undertook a review of the formula for calculating the facilitation rate in late 2003. The decision to change the calculation formula was made in April 2004. (2) The facilitation standard requires that 95% of arriving passengers will be processed through the Entry Control Point (ECP) within 30 minutes of joining the ECP queue. The facilitation rate is calculated from: (a) the “chocks” time of each arriving aircraft (b) a “pre-queue” time (c) the time each passenger gets processed through the ECP The pre-queue time varies between airports and takes account of the delay from aircraft arrival time to when passengers join the ECP queue. This pre-queue time is the sum of median times taken for travellers to disembark the aircraft and to walk or bus to the ECP queuing area. The table below shows the median pre-queue times for passengers for each major international airport. Median pre-queue times per airport Airport Median disemMedian walk/bus Total walk and disbarkation time time (minutes) embarkation time (minutes) (minutes) Sydney 11 5 16 Melbourne 11 3 14

title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing
